comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:6.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0.1
Build ID: 20110830092941

Steps to reproduce:

Start FF right into private browsing from jump list. Change window size (in private browsing). Exit private browsing.


Actual results:

Window size ramains the same as it was in private browsing.


Expected results:

Window should be set to the size which was in last session of normal browsing.

Do they get stripped off in getBrowserState?  The PB service doesn't modify the browser state it receives from sessionstore.

comments.text:
Build identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:8.0a2) Gecko/20110915 Firefox/8.0a2; build ID: 20110915042012

Verified this on Aurora and could not reproduce.
Steps:
1. Start Aurora
2. Maximize browsed window
3. Start Private Browsig
4. Restore browser window/ change its dimension
5. Stop Private Browsing

Result: Browser displayed window as maximized

comments.text:
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:9.0a1) Gecko/20110913 Firefox/9.0a1

Reproducible for me on the Nightly:

1. Start Firefox Private Browsing from jump list.
2. Minimize Firefox window.
3. Stop private browsing from the menu.

The window has the same dimensions as in Private browsing mode.
comments.author: virgil.dicu@softvision.ro
comments.creator: virgil.dicu@softvision.ro
comments.raw_text:
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:9.0a1) Gecko/20110913 Firefox/9.0a1

Reproducible for me on the Nightly:

1. Start Firefox Private Browsing from jump list.
2. Minimize Firefox window.
3. Stop private browsing from the menu.

The window has the same dimensions as in Private browsing mode.

Confirming based on comment 5. Question is whether or not this is desired behaviour. If this is something that used to happen and it has regressed then we need a regression window. If this is as designed then we need to evaluate whether we want to change that design.

Pending developer/UX feedback.
comments.author: u279076@disabled.tld
